This is Graham Hovey, recording the first in a new series of radio Letters from Ita4y
for the Rational Association of Educational Broadcasters — the RAEB Network.
My guide book calls Perugia "the empress of hill-set cities" in Italy and I'll settle
for that designation, I fell hard for this empress at first sight on the mid-summer day
in 1944 when she was liberated by the British army. And I have gone back to Perugia on
every occasion when I could find an excuse for doing so. I am not the only American who
feels this way. You will meet another in a few minutes.
The ancient heart of the city of Perugia rests at the top of a steep hill, some 1500
feet above sea level and close to the geographic center of the Italian peninsula. From
this crest you can look out across hundreds of acres of the rolling countryside of the
region of Umbria, of which Perugia is the capital.
Umbria is a lovely patchwork of hills and valleys in greens and browns, punctuated
with slender elms and oaks and poplars — and, of course, the cypress trees and umbrella -
pines which do so much for so much of the Italian landscape.
From Perugia’s crest, on a clear day, without half trying, you can see Assisi, the
city of St. Francis, white against the side of Mt. Subasio, 25 kilometers to the east.
Off the other side you may glimpse the mirror that is Lake Trasimeno, where Hannibal won a
battle, but not a war against the RomaHs in 217 B. C. At dusk, off this crest, you see
sunets which critics would call exaggerated if ever a painter could capture them on canvass,
But its location is not all that makes Perugia the empress.
In some respects, Perugia is a modem city of nearly 100,000, sprawling ever farther
down the hillside. But its main street runs for less than half a mile along the crest,
through the ancient heart of the city.
That street must be one of the most remarkable in the world. They call it the Corso
Vannucci, in honor of the great renaissance painter, Pietro Vannucci — Raphael’s teacher,
who took the name Perugino, after the city where he lived and worked.
Along that short street of several hundred yards, if you stroll slowly and observe
carefully and glance frequently down the vicoli. the side lanes that spin off the Corso,
you can spot evidences of all the great periods in Perugia’s known historyi from Etruscan
through Roman through me die val and renaissance to the up—to—date. And on the Corso
Vannucci in Perugia, one can stroll slowly and observe leisurely.
In all parts of Italy you find pedestrians not convinced that the automobile is here
to stay. But in Perugia every evening, the authorities make testament of their faith that
people are more important than autosj that going "a spasso," as Italians say — strolling
for pleasure in a lovely setting — is an essential part of the good life. For two hours
they block off the Corso to all vehicles for almost its entire length. And by the thou¬
sands, the Peruginians come out in good weather to take the air before supper, strolling
back and forth with their friends, unhurried and undisturbed.
Some of the strollers will linger for a while at one end of the Corso, where the hill
drops away from the wall in sharp staggers. For this is the best spot from which to watch
the elements gradually assemble, then gradually dissemble, those exaggerated sunsets over
Lake Trasimeno way — sunsets against whose crimson is always silhouetted a single, thin
line of now-black trees on the rim of the western horizon.
